Comment: People misunderstand how West Virginia became a state, it was largely a bureacratic process that was not supported by the majority of voters living in WV. If you look at the [map of the 1860 election](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/70/PresidentialCounty1860Colorbrewer.gif) you will see that WV voted the same as all the rest of Virginia. The vote of 1861 on Virginia's secession saw about half of [WV counties voting for secession](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9a/Wvmapagain.png). The populous counties along the Ohio/Penn. border rejected secession and a miniature civil war took place in WV, with about equal amounts of [men going to the Confederate](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Confederate_recruitment_in_West_Virginia.jpg) and Union armies. The move to create a new state was not popular, at it's height in 1863 it brought out less than 28,000 votes, there were almost 80,000 voters in the counties. Congress and the president did not care about the low results and made it a state in 1863, with a state government that controlled less than half the state and couldn't meet it's requirements for soldiers. The new state government held on until 1872 when full voting rights were restored and they were swept from office. Former Confederates were elected and a new state constitution was written along the lines of the old Virginia constitution.  The development of Virginia as it was progressing west at the start of the war was disrupted, the WV state government was more vulnerable to influence and corruption and the natural resources of the region were [controlled by outsides interests](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/67/Confederate_recruitment_in_West_Virginia.jpg). That system stayed in place until the failure of the coal industry, which did not build infrastructure or sustainable communities once they had left.
